variant.question:
In a twin engined jet aircraft with six passenger seats, and a Maximum Certified Take-off Mass of 5 650 kg
 What is the required enroute obstacle clearance, with one engine inoperative during drift down towards the alternate airport?

Refer to figure or CAP698 file 4.1. A flight has been planned to operate at the maximum field-length limited take-off mass (FLLTOM). This was based upon the planned runway being 04 and the forecast wind to be light and variable. During the taxi, an aircraft just ahead was cleared to take-off and the reported wind was 270° (M)/20 kt. What observations should the flight crew raise given this updated wind?

options.text: The aircraft performance should be re-calculated prior to take-off because there is now a tailwind of approximately 13 kt.
The take-off can be commenced because the updated wind means that the new headwind has increased the take-off performance and therefore increased the maximum FLLTOM.
The departure can be continued because the planned take-off mass is based on a calculation that included the maximum tailwind.
The approximate headwind of 15 kt means the aircraft should return to stand because the actual take-off distance has decreased and therefore the take-off mass can be increased.

variant.question: Which of the following provides maximum obstacle clearance during climb?

options.text: The speed for maximum climb angle VX.
The speed, at which the flaps may be selected one position further UP.
The speed for maximum rate of climb.

variant.question: Which of the following provides maximum obstacle clearance during climb?

options.text: The speed for maximum climb angle V~X~.
The speed for maximum rate of climb.
The speed, at which the flaps may be selected one position further UP.

variant.question: Which of the following provides maximum obstacle clearance during climb?

options.text: The speed for maximum climb angle Vx.
The speed, at which the flaps may be selected one position further UP.
The speed for maximum rate of climb.

variant.question:
The departure airport reports an air temp of -5 C . Using the data below,which statement is correct? (SEL OAT is equivalent to the assumed temprature of FLEX)
V1: 132 kt
Flaps: 5 degrees
VR: 132 kt
SEL OAT: +59 C
V2: 139 kt

options.text: SEL OAT wil force the engine control computer to think the air temprature is +59C and therefore that the air density is low and the engine requires less fuel to maintain the correct fuel/air ratio.this leads to less thrust being produced.

SEL OAT is a parameter that is used to modify the take-off performance calculation in order find the appropriate thrust setting and is NOT entered in any aeroplane systems. The aeroplane can only work with the actual air temprature.

By entering the SEL OAT value the engine will produce a greater amount of thrust since a higher SEL OAT value will tell the engine that the air is warmer. This m that more feul is required to maintain the thrust when the air is less dense.

The SEL value will only be considered when it is lower than the air temprature at the airport. it is the lowest of either the SEL OAT or the airport air temprature that determines the take-off thrust for the engines.

 V1: 132 kt

options.text: SEL OAT wil force the engine control computer to think the air temprature is +59C and therefore that the air density is low and the engine requires less fuel to maintain the correct fuel/air ratio.this leads to less thrust being produced.

SEL OAT is a parameter that is used to modify the take-off performance calculation in order find the appropriate thrust setting and is NOT entered in any aeroplane systems. The aeroplane can only work with the actual air temprature.

By entering the SEL OAT value the engine will produce a greater amount of thrust since a higher SEL OAT value will tell the engine that the air is warmer. This m that more feul is required to maintain the thrust when the air is less dense.

The SEL value will only be considered when it is lower than the air temprature at the airport. it is the lowest of either the SEL OAT or the airport air temprature that determines the take-off thrust for the engines.

Consider the methods listed below for improving the Field-Length Limited Take-Off Mass (FLL TOM) of an MRJT aeroplane. Which of the methods does the pilot have direct influence over?
1. Use flaps 15 instead of flaps 5 to increase the FLL TOM by approximately 600 kg. 
 2. Decide NOT to use engine anti-ice to increase the FLL TOM by 450 kg. 
 3. Choose the runway with the most favourable wind component to increase the FLL TOM by the credit for any wind improvements. 
 4. Perform a packs-off take-off to increase the FLL TOM by 550 kg.

options.text: 1 and 4, to improve the FLLTOM by 1 150 kg.
1, 2, and 4, to improve the FLLTOM by 1 600 kg.
3 and 4, to improve the FLLTOM by 550 kg plus the credit for any wind improvement.
2 and 3, to improve the FLLTOM by 450 kg plus the credit for any wind improvement.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about the take-off speeds is true?

A pilot is operating a series of short-haul flights. The landing at one destination was performed at the maximum landing mass and the aircraft is only scheduled to spend a short time on the ground prior to the next departure. Brake temperature...

options.text: may limit the turnaround time for brake cooling, to ensure the brakes will have adequate capacity to absorb the energy in the event of a rejected take-off.
may limit the turnaround time, to ensure that the wheel fuse plugs will NOT melt during the subsequent taxi-out or take-off.
should NOT limit the turnaround time, because the regulated take-off mass calculation will take into account brake temperature considerations.
should NOT limit the turnaround time, because brakes are mainly used during the landing phase of a flight, and there is NO need to delay the departure.

If an engine failure is recognized after reaching V1, the take-off must be aborted.
V1 is sometimes greater than the rotation speed VR.
V1 may not be less than V2 min, the minimum take-off safety speed.

There are obstacles close to the end of the runway requiring use of more flaps to reduce the take off distance.

is an airspeed at which the aeroplane is airborne but below 35 feet and the pilot is assumed to have made a decision to continue or discontinue the take-off .

variant.question:
What will be the result if the pilot decides to set a TOGA thrust instead of a FLEX thrust, when commencing the take-off run, after having entered the following data into the FMS?V~1~: 165 kt 
 V~R~:170 kt 
 V~2~: 174 kt 
 T~FLEX~: 46°C

options.text: The engine will achieve a higher thrust setting and take-off performance will be improved when compared to the calculated values.

The aeroplane will have an improved climb performance but because the speeds are calculated for a reduced thrust setting, the aeroplane will fail to achieve the required take-off distance and obstacle clearance.
It is NOT legal to commence a take-off run with a thrust setting other than the one calculated as the take-off performance cannot be assured using incorrect speeds.
The take-off speeds will be incorrect and too low. If an engine were to fail at the most critical time for a continued take-off, the aeroplane would fail to achieve the calculated performance.

Refer to the annex or CAP 698 Figure 4.31. An MRJT aeroplane has a generator failure during the take-off roll and the Captain decides to reject the take-off and taxi off the runway to hold on a taxiway. The generator is reset after 10 minutes and found to be functioning again and so the flight can resume. Given the following information, how long in total should the Captain wait before a further take-off, assuming any taxi distance is negligible?
  • Take-off mass: 57500 kg
  • Speed when fault occurred: 90 kt
  • Speed when rejection commenced: 100 kt
  • Retardation: Maximum braking and reverse thrust
  • Wind: Light and variable
  • Elevation: 1400 ft
  • QNH: 1013.25 hPa
  • OAT: -10°C

options.text: It is recommended to wait for approximately 35 minutes having used maximum braking and reverse thrust.
It is recommended to wait for approximately 50 minutes if some credit is given for using reverse thrust.
Only ground cooling is recommended, which means that a new take-off may be commenced now that the fault has been rectified
It is recommended to wait for approximately 40 minutes after using maximum manual braking.

options.text: The engines are pressure limited at lower temperature, at higher temperatures they are temperature limited.
At temperatures higher than ISA the flat rated engines determine the climb limit mass.
At higher temperatures the VMBE determines the climb limit mass.
At lower temperatures one has to take the danger of icing into account.

Contamination on the runway will increase the maximum mass because of the reduced resistance against the wheels.

Higher temperatures will increase the maximum mass because of the upward vertical airflow.

Refer to figure or CAP file 4.31. The pilot of an MRJT aeroplane after recognizing a generator failure during the take-off roll, he/she decides to reject the take-off and taxi off the runway to hold on a taxiway. Resetting the generator after 10 minutes, he/she realizes that it functions properly, so the flight can resume. Given the following information, what is the minimum cooling time before the next take-off, assuming that the taxi distance is negligible?Take-off mass: 57 500 kg 
 Speed when fault occurred: 90 kt 
 Speed when rejection commenced: 100 kt 
 Retardation: Maximum braking and reverse thrust 
 Wind: Light and variable 
 Elevation: 1 400 ft 
 QNH: 1013.25 hPa 
 OAT: -10°C

options.text: It is recommended to wait for approximately 50 minutes if some credit is given for using reverse thrust.
Only ground cooling is recommended, which means that a new take-off may be commenced now that the fault has been rectified.
It is recommended to wait for approximately 40 minutes after using maximum manual braking.
It is recommended to wait for approximately 35 minutes having used maximum braking and reverse thrust.
